CITY OF TARPON SPRINGS WWF RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The City of Tarpon Springs Advanced Wastewater Treatment Facility (AWTF) has been identified as a facility that is subject to reporting under the Florida Accidental Release Prevention and Risk Management Planning (ARP/RMP) Act.  The toxic chemical threshold quantities, which were met to identify the facility, relate to the stored amounts of both chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The ARP/RMP Act delineates three (3) specific levels of processes.  Of the three levels defined, the City's AWTF qualifies as a Level 3 Process facility.  As a result of this designation, the facility is required to address specific process safety criteria in the Risk Management Program.  This information and other pertinent information are included in the City's RMP document.

The objective of the City of Tarpon Springs Risk Management Program (RMP) is to provide information that will define action(s) that will effectively prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment and mitigate the severity of any accidental releases that might occur.

In order to achieve these objectives, the Risk Management Program presents information for the City's Level 3 processes and outlines the emergency response program for the facility.

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

The City of Tarpon Springs takes a proactive approach to safety and compliance with all State and Federal rules and regulations.  Pertinent AWTF staff members have completed comprehensive training courses related to the proper use, handling, storage, and emergency response procedures associated with chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The City's Risk Management Program specifically addresses staff activities for various scenarios related to potential leaks and emergency situations, while placing emphasis on predictive maintenance and preventing accidental chemical releases.  Written Standard Operati

ng Procedures (SOPs) have been developed and implemented for changing one (1) ton chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders. 

Entrance into the facility is accessed using programmed magnetic identification cards, which record the time and employee number of each entry into the facility.  The entry gate is monitored at two (2) locations within the control building using video surveillance equipment and an intercom system, which is used to grant or deny access to the facility.

Additionally,video surveillance equipment is in use at the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage buildings and the chemical feed equipment areas.  Installation of this equipment has provided an effective means to monitor the storage buildings, ensuring authorized personnel are safe and providing notice of unauthorized persons in the areas.  The video monitoring also provides staff with additional ability to detect equipment malfunctions. 

Images of these locations are displayed on a designated monitor located in the operational control building and at a shared monitor located in the reception area.

The facility and the regulated substances handled

The City is permitted to operate a domestic wastewater treatment plant, permit #FL0030406, by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP).  The City's AWTF is currently a 4.0 MGD Annual Average Daily Flow domestic wastewater treatment plant Type I, Bardenpho process, with biological nutrient removal (BNR).

The City's AWTF uses chlorine gas for disinfection of the facility's effluent and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) for dechlorination prior to discharge to the Anclote River.  The chlorine storage and dosing process is located within the perimeter of the facility, while the sulfur dioxide storage and dechlorination system is located remotely at the outfall to the Anclote River, approximately 850 feet north of the AWTF.

The chlorination system uses two (2) five hundred pound per day (500 ppd) chlorinators and one (1) two hundred pound per day

(200 ppd) chlorinator to combine chlorine in its gaseous form with water, creating an aqueous chlorine solution.  The chlorine solution is injected into the filtered effluent flow as the water enters the chlorine contact chamber.  The chlorine solution dose is determined using an ultrasonic meter that measures the flow of the filtered effluent.

The chlorine contact chamber serves to provide the detention time needed for effective disinfection.  Effluent flow from the contact chamber flows to two (2) two million-gallon (2.0 MG) reuse water ground storage tanks.  After the ground storage tanks fill to their maximum capacity, the effluent level in the chlorine contact chamber increases until it overflows, or is automatically controlled by the facility's Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system, to a transmission pipe, which discharges at the Anclote River outfall.

Prior to discharge to the Anclote River, the effluent is dechlorinated using a combination of sodium bisulfite and sulfur dioxide. The gaseous dechlorination system uses one (1) five hundred pound per day (500 ppd) sulfunator and one (1) two hundred pound per day (200 ppd) sulfunator, combining sulfur dioxide in its gaseous form with water to create an aqueous sulfur dioxide solution.  The operation of the sulfunators is similar to that of the chlorinators.  The sulfur dioxide solution is dispensed just upstream of the Anclote River outfall weir.

Both the chlorination and dechlorination processes are subject to 40 CFR Part 68 Level 3 requirements for the following three reasons:  

1.    Both processes store regulated substances (i.e. chlorine and sulfur dioxide) above the threshold quantities;

2.    Both processes have the potential to impact public receptors (both human and environmental) within the distance to an endpoint from a worst-case release; and 

3.    Both processes are subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management regulations.

In order

to have a sufficient amount on-site for treatment, seven (7) 2,000-lbs. chlorine cylinders are present at the AWTF at all times.  The cylinder containers are stored in an elevated 17 by 31-foot concrete building, approximately 70 feet west of the operations building.  The cylinders are maneuvered using an over-head electric chain hoist and placed on trunnions to facilitate correct cylinder operating position.  The EPA threshold quantity for chlorine is 2,500 lbs.

Sulfur dioxide storage is similar to the above noted chlorine storage with minimal exception; four (4) 2,000-lbs. sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) cylinders are stored at the dechlorination building located approximately 850 feet north of the WWTP.  The cylinder containers are stored in an elevated 15 by 25-foot concrete building similar to that of the chlorine storage building.  The cylinders are maneuvered in the same fashion and placed on trunnions with an electric chain hoist.  The EPA threshold quantity for sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) is 5,000 lbs.

Both the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage buildings are equipped with exhaust fans, emergency-breathing apparatus, leak detection devices in the storage bays and equipment rooms (and are protected from vehicle impacts with audible and visual alarms to operations staff along with appropriate signs warning of toxic chemicals.  Alarms are connected to SCADA system for immediate emergency notifications.

General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps

The Risk Management Program (RMP) has been developed and implemented by the City of Tarpon Springs AWTF in accordance with Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act and 40 CFR Part 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.  

In-house refresher training is provided for pertinent staff members on the proper use of the "B" repair kit and Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA).  This training is provided annually at a minimum.  Additionally, the City's Fire Department conducts an

information gathering visit annually.  These annual visits serve as a review for the Fire Department with regard to the nature of all chemicals stored on-site, and the quantities and locations of the same.

Preventative maintenance is performed on all chlorination and dechlorination equipment by an outside contractor that has been factory trained on a semi-annual basis.  The City also has a work order system to address any noted equipment problems in a timely manner.  Both the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage buildings are equipped with leak detection devices, which are checked monthly for proper working order.

Five year accident history

In the last five years, there have been no known releases associated with either of the Level 3 Processes located at the AWTF.  Consequently no known off-site impacts were reported as a result.  

Emergency Response Program

The City's emergency notification, response, and first aid procedures, located in Section 6 of the City's Risk Management Program, are written in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68.  The procedures take into account existing measures established by the City, emergency responders, and AWTF operations experts.

In the event of a chemical release emergency at the AWTF, the following agencies are to be notified immediately:

1.Both the Police Department (727-938-2849) and the Fire Department (727-938-3737);

2.The Florida State Warning Point (800-320-0519);

3.The National Response Center (800-424-8802); and

4.The Local Emergency Planning Committee for District 8 (727-570-5151).

While release notification may be forwarded from one agency to another, the Superintendent of the City's AWTF is responsible for verifying that all appropriate agencies are notified in a timely manner.

Emergency response procedures have been developed for stopping minor chlorine or sulfur dioxide leaks.  Only trained personnel wearing appropriate breathing apparatus, personal protective equipment (PPE), and carrying a two-way radio or a
cellular phone are permitted to enter the area of an accidental release.  Hazmat will be contacted to respond to any serious situation that cannot be handled immediately by AWTF staff.
